questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, and abdominal pain. He reports memory loss and reveals that he works at a battery recycling plant. On examination, a noticeable foot drop in both lower extremities is seen. Laboratory testing shows elevated blood lead levels. Which enzyme is affected in the given scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Lead poisoning primarily inhibits the enzyme Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase (ALAD), leading to disruptions in the heme synthesis pathway and accumulation of heme precursors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is found dead in his home, and the forensic team is called to assess the time of death. Upon examination, the man exhibits stiffness in his eyelids and lower jaw, but his chest and arms remain flexible. Based on Nysten’s rule, rigor mortis develops sequentially from the head downward through specific muscle groups. In what order does rigor mortis typically develop, starting from the earliest affected muscles to the latest?

options.label: B
options.text: Myocardium, eyelids, neck and lower jaw, face, chest

options.label: C
options.text: Upper extremities, chest, face, eyelids, neck and jaw

options.label: D
options.text: Fingers and toes, legs, upper extremities, abdomen, chest

questions.correct_answer: B. Myocardium, eyelids, neck and lower jaw, face, chest
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups, beginning from the head and progressing down the body. According to this rule, rigor mortis first affects the myocardium, followed by the eyelids, neck, and lower jaw. It then progresses to the face, chest, upper extremities, abdomen, legs, and finally the fingers and toes. This systematic progression helps forensic experts estimate the time of death by observing which muscle groups have stiffened, reflecting rigor mortis development from top to bottom.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nysten’s rule outlines the predictable sequence of rigor mortis onset, starting with the smallest muscles and progressing downward: myocardium, eyelids, neck and jaw, face, chest, upper extremities, abdomen, legs, and finally fingers and toes. Recognizing this pattern is essential in forensic pathology to help determine the approximate time of death based on the extent of muscle stiffness observed.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts of the body based on the position at the time of death. In drowning cases, it affects the face, neck, chest, and limbs, not just the lower limbs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of snake bite:
  • ➤ Treatment of snake bite:
  • ➤ First Aid treatment have limited role. Reassure the patient, immobilize the limb and keep it below the heart level. Light pressure can be applied in neurotoxic snakes. Anti-snake venom (ASV) is the main treatment for snake bite. It contains antivenom against the 4 common poisonous snakes in India (Cobra, Krait, Russel’s viper and saw scaled viper). It does not contain antivenom against humped pit viper, which is found in some states of India, but still can be partially effective in it due to cross antibodies formation. Treatment in addition to ASV: Vasculotoxic symptoms: Dialysis and Blood Transfusion Musculotoxic symptoms: Dialysis Neurotoxic snakes: Ventilation and Neostigmine (along with atropine)

It does not contain antivenom against humped pit viper, which is found in some states of India, but still can be partially effective in it due to cross antibodies formation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is found deceased at his home, and a forensic examination is conducted to determine the time of death. On inspection, the body shows prominent greenish-black streaks visible along the blood vessels on the skin, primarily over the lower extremities, resembling a branching pattern. The skin has a discolored appearance ranging from green to black. Based on these findings, which postmortem condition is most likely represented in the image?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by the visible appearance of blood vessels on the skin as greenish-black streaks. This condition occurs due to the breakdown of hemoglobin in the blood, leading to the formation of sulfmethemoglobin, which causes the characteristic discoloration of the skin. Marbling typically starts around 24 hours after death and becomes more prominent within 36-48 hours. The process is part of the early stages of decomposition, where the visible blood vessels create a marbled appearance due to bacterial gas production and the breakdown of hemoglobin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Livor mortis: Livor mortis, also known as postmortem hypostasis, refers to the pooling of blood in dependent parts of the body, leading to purplish-red discoloration of the skin. It does not cause the greenish-black streaks along blood vessels seen in marbling.
  • • A. Livor mortis:
  • • C. Tardieu spots: Tardieu spots are petechial hemorrhages seen on the skin, conjunctivae, and other mucosal surfaces, often associated with asphyxial deaths. They do not present with the distinct marbling pattern seen on the skin in decomposition.
  • • C. Tardieu spots:
  • • D. Putrefaction: Putrefaction refers to the process of decay and decomposition of the body, characterized by bloating, gas formation, and the release of foul odors. While marbling is an early stage of putrefaction, the term putrefaction alone does not specifically describe the marbling pattern of the blood vessels.
  • • D. Putrefaction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marbling is an early postmortem change characterized by greenish-black discoloration of the skin along blood vessels due to the formation of sulfmethemoglobin during decomposition. This change typically begins around 24 hours after death and becomes prominent within 36-48 hours, serving as an important indicator of the time frame in postmortem examinations.

questions.text: An abandoned deceased male fetus was discovered and brought for autopsy. The following findings were noted: (AIIMS NOV 2016) Crown-to-rump length (CRL): 23 cm Total length (head to feet): 63 cm Eyes open Pupillary membrane absent Testes located at the superficial inguinal ring Fetal weight: 1000 gm Based on these observations, what is the estimated age of the fetus? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Several key findings point towards a fetal age of 7 months:
  • • Pupillary membrane: The absence of the pupillary membrane indicates a fetal age of at least 7 months, as this structure typically disappears around this time. Testes location: The descent of the testes to the superficial inguinal ring is also consistent with a 7-month-old fetus. Fetal weight: The fetal weight of 1000 gm falls within the expected range for a 7-month-old fetus (900-1200 gm).
  • • Pupillary membrane: The absence of the pupillary membrane indicates a fetal age of at least 7 months, as this structure typically disappears around this time.
  • • Pupillary membrane:
  • • Testes location: The descent of the testes to the superficial inguinal ring is also consistent with a 7-month-old fetus.
  • • Testes location:
  • • Fetal weight: The fetal weight of 1000 gm falls within the expected range for a 7-month-old fetus (900-1200 gm).
  • • Fetal weight:
  • • Additionally, we can estimate the age using Hasse's rule , which states:
  • • Hasse's rule
  • • For the first 5 months: Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (CHL) in cm. After 5 months: Age in months = CHL in cm / 5 We know CRL = 2/3 CHL, so CHL = 3/2 CRL = (3/2) * 23 cm = 34.5 cm Since the fetus is older than 5 months, we use the second part of Hasse's rule: Age in months = 34.5 cm / 5 = 7 months (approximately)
  • • For the first 5 months: Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (CHL) in cm.
  • • After 5 months: Age in months = CHL in cm / 5
  • • We know CRL = 2/3 CHL, so CHL = 3/2 CRL = (3/2) * 23 cm = 34.5 cm
  • • Since the fetus is older than 5 months, we use the second part of Hasse's rule: Age in months = 34.5 cm / 5 = 7 months (approximately)
  • • This further supports the estimated fetal age of 7 months.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • a. 5 months: At 5 months, the pupillary membrane is still present, and the testes are usually located higher in the abdomen. b. 6 months: Similar to 5 months, the pupillary membrane is still present at 6 months, and the testes have not yet descended to the superficial inguinal ring. d. 8 months: At 8 months, the testes would likely be palpable in the scrotum, and the fetal weight would be higher (1.5-2 kg).
  • • a. 5 months: At 5 months, the pupillary membrane is still present, and the testes are usually located higher in the abdomen.
  • • a. 5 months:
  • • b. 6 months: Similar to 5 months, the pupillary membrane is still present at 6 months, and the testes have not yet descended to the superficial inguinal ring.
  • • b. 6 months:
  • • d. 8 months: At 8 months, the testes would likely be palpable in the scrotum, and the fetal weight would be higher (1.5-2 kg).
  • • d. 8 months:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The absence of the pupillary membrane, the descent of the testes to the superficial inguinal ring, and a fetal weight of around 1000 gm are key indicators of a 7-month-old fetus. Hasse's rule can provide an additional estimate of fetal age based on crown-heel length.

questions.text: In a Partogram, where do you start plotting the cervical dilatation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) On the alert line

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the WHO modified partograph, labor progression is charted using alert and action lines. The cervical dilatation is plotted starting in the active phase of labor, typically at 4 cm dilation.
  • • Alert Line : Represents a cervical dilation rate of 1 cm per hour. The first marking of cervical dilatation should be on this line. Action Line : Plotted 4 hours to the right of the alert line. It indicates when intervention should be considered if labor is not progressing as expected.
  • • Alert Line : Represents a cervical dilation rate of 1 cm per hour. The first marking of cervical dilatation should be on this line.
  • • Alert Line
  • • Action Line : Plotted 4 hours to the right of the alert line. It indicates when intervention should be considered if labor is not progressing as expected.
  • • Action Line
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. On the action line: Plotting starts on the alert line, not the action line. The action line is used for intervention planning.
  • • Option A. On the action line:
  • • Option B. Before the action line: This is incorrect as the plotting starts on the alert line.
  • • Option B. Before the action line:
  • • Option D. After the alert line: This is incorrect since plotting should start on the alert line.
  • • Option D. After the alert line:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a Partogram, cervical dilatation is first plotted on the alert line, which indicates the expected rate of progress in labor.
  • ➤ Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition. Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

questions.text: Shape of Trapezius muscle is? ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Triangular

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The trapezius muscle is a large, triangular and paired muscle located on the posterior aspect of the neck and thorax. Each trapezius muscle is flat and triangularly shaped, with the base of the triangle situated along the vertebral column (the muscle's origin) and the apex pointing toward the tip of the shoulder (the muscle's insertion).
  • • The trapezius muscle is a large, triangular and paired muscle located on the posterior aspect of the neck and thorax.
  • • Each trapezius muscle is flat and triangularly shaped, with the base of the triangle situated along the vertebral column (the muscle's origin) and the apex pointing toward the tip of the shoulder (the muscle's insertion).
  • • Trapezius muscle shape: Considering left or right side - triangular shape Considering both sides together - diamond shaped, hence named "trapezius"
  • • Trapezius muscle shape: Considering left or right side - triangular shape Considering both sides together - diamond shaped, hence named "trapezius"
  • • Considering left or right side - triangular shape Considering both sides together - diamond shaped, hence named "trapezius"
  • • Considering left or right side - triangular shape
  • • Considering both sides together - diamond shaped, hence named "trapezius"

Educational Objective:

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Polycationic, Neutral, polyanionic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The filterability of substances through the kidney glomerular filtration barrier depends on their charge and size. Polycationic substances (positively charged) filter most readily, neutral substances have intermediate filterability, and polyanionic substances (negatively charged) have the least filterability due to repulsion by the negatively charged barrier.

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2019)

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to detect the presence of pathogens by allowing the vector to feed on or be injected with the patient's tissue, then examining the vector for the pathogen. Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue is a classic example of this diagnostic method.

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. C5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most likely cause of the inability to abduct the arm is a C5 root lesion.
  • • The C5 spinal nerve plays a crucial role in controlling shoulder abduction. It gives rise to the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. Damage or compression of the C5 nerve root or axillary nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to difficulty in abducting the arm.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. C4: The C4 spinal nerve does not directly innervate the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction. It primarily supplies sensory information to areas of the neck and upper shoulders.
  • • Option A. C4:
  • • Option C . C6: The C6 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow flexion and wrist extension, not shoulder abduction. Damage to the C6 nerve root would affect these functions rather than shoulder abduction.
  • • Option C
  • • C6:

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dL and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV

questions.correct_answer: A. 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 2-3 L of Normal saline over 1-3 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case of DKA presenting with signs of dehydration and shock, the initial management should focus on aggressive fluid resuscitation to stabilize the patient before initiating insulin therapy. This approach not only addresses the immediate life-threatening condition but also prepares the body for further metabolic correction.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21E/DKA/Chapter 404

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serotonin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • All of the options listed increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.
  • • Gastric Acid Secretion:
  • • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl). Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.
  • • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl).
  • • Parietal Cells:
  • • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.
  • • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells:
  • • Stimulation of ECL Cells:
  • • Stimulation of ECL Cells:
  • • Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells. Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells. Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.
  • • Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells.
  • • Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells.
  • • Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.
  • • Role of Serotonin:
  • • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.
  • • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.
  • • Serotonin:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gastrin: Incorrect. Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option A. Gastrin:
  • • Option B. Histamine: Incorrect. Histamine increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option B. Histamine:
  • • Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option C. Acetylcholine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion, while gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine stimulate it. Serotonin also stimulates mucus production and increases intestinal motility, acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

  • ➤ (2nd Best Method)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports to the police after being sexually assaulted by her employer. During the forensic examination, white stains were found on her clothing. To identify the nature of the stains, Barberio’s test was performed, revealing the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals. What substance is detected by Barberio’s test?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Barberio’s test is used to detect the presence of spermine, a component of semen secreted by the prostate gland. In this test, an alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the dried seminal stain, which reacts to form yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate. The presence of these crystals confirms the detection of spermine, indicating that the stain likely contains semen. Barberio’s test is part of the microchemical tests used in the presumptive identification of seminal stains.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Acid phosphatase: Acid phosphatase is an enzyme found in high concentrations in semen, primarily produced by the prostate gland. Although commonly used in seminal stain detection, it is not identified by Barberio’s test, but rather through an enzymatic colorimetric reaction.
  • • A. Acid phosphatase:
  • • B. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA): PSA is a protein produced by the prostate gland and is a marker used in the confirmatory tests for semen, especially when no sperm cells are present. However, Barberio’s test does not detect PSA.
  • • B. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA):
  • • D. Creatine phosphokinase: Creatine phosphokinase is found in spermatozoa and can be used in some confirmatory tests for semen detection. However, it is not the target substance in Barberio’s test.
  • • D. Creatine phosphokinase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Barberio’s test is a microchemical test used for the presumptive detection of spermine, a prostatic component of semen, by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate. This test is part of the forensic analysis of seminal stains, providing valuable evidence in sexual assault investigations.

questions.text: Identify the acid base disorder in a patient with the following values: pH- 7.2 and pCO 2 – 80 mm Hg? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • As pH = 7.2 of the patient’s blood is lower than normal blood pH= 7.35-7.45, so, it’s a case of acidosis. As the acidosis is due to pCO 2 = 80 mm of Hg that is higher than normal pCO 2 = 35-45 mm of Hg, so, it’s a case of respiratory acidosis rather than metabolic acidosis which occurs due to decreased HCO 3 - ions.
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option A. Metabolic acidosis: This condition is characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to a primary reduction in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not associated with elevated pCO2 levels, which are seen in respiratory acidosis.
  • • Option
  • • A. Metabolic acidosis:
  • • Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary increase in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not consistent with the low pH and high pCO2 levels seen in the patient.
  • • Option
  • • B. Metabolic alkalosis:
  • • Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary decrease in pCO2 levels, often caused by hyperventilation. It is the opposite of the patient's condition, which shows low pH and high pCO2 levels.
  • • Option
  • • D. Respiratory alkalosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Respiratory acidosis is indicated by a low blood pH and elevated pCO2 levels, suggesting impaired respiratory function and CO2 retention as the primary cause of the acidosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Dinesh Puri 3 rd ed/pg-15
  • ➤ Ref: Dinesh Puri 3 rd ed/pg-15

questions.text: Match the following declarations with their primary focus or motive: (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Declaration of Geneva (1948): This declaration is a modernized version of the Hippocratic Oath, outlining the ethical duties and responsibilities of physicians. Declaration of Helsinki (1964): This declaration sets ethical guidelines for medical research involving human subjects, emphasizing the importance of informed consent and the protection of participants' well-being. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): This declaration addresses the role of physicians in preventing and opposing torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment. Declaration of Oslo (1970): This declaration pertains to therapeutic abortion, outlining principles and guidelines for the medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Declaration of Geneva (1948): This declaration is a modernized version of the Hippocratic Oath, outlining the ethical duties and responsibilities of physicians.
  • • Declaration of Geneva (1948):
  • • Declaration of Helsinki (1964): This declaration sets ethical guidelines for medical research involving human subjects, emphasizing the importance of informed consent and the protection of participants' well-being.
  • • Declaration of Helsinki (1964):
  • • Declaration of Tokyo (1975): This declaration addresses the role of physicians in preventing and opposing torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment.
  • • Declaration of Tokyo (1975):
  • • Declaration of Oslo (1970): This declaration pertains to therapeutic abortion, outlining principles and guidelines for the medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Declaration of Oslo (1970):
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • The other options present incorrect pairings between the declarations and their primary motives.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It's essential to be familiar with these key declarations and their significance in medical ethics and human rights. These documents guide the conduct of physicians and researchers worldwide.

questions.text: Ketosis is common in type 1 DM due to: ( INICET Nov 2020) 1. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids 2. Increased mobilization of fat from the adipose cell 3. Decreased acetyl Co in TCA cycle 4. Increased beta-hydroxy butyrate synthase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ketosis in type 1 diabetes mellitus is caused by increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue, decreased entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, and increased production of ketone bodies, particularly beta-hydroxybutyrate.

This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

It is the main restraint to the posterior translation of the knee i.e., the backward gliding of the tibia over the femur. While evaluating the patient during physical examination, PCL is the main restraint in the posterior drawer test.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is found unresponsive in a freshwater lake after being submerged for an unknown duration. He is immediately transported to the emergency department, where resuscitation efforts are initiated. On examination, the patient is in a drowsy state with a pulse rate of 140/min and a respiratory rate of 30/min. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals metabolic acidosis, based on these findings, what are the typical physiological changes associated with freshwater drowning?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In cases of freshwater drowning, several key physiological changes occur due to the rapid absorption of large volumes of hypotonic water. The excessive absorption of water leads to hemodilution, which results in a significant decrease in plasma sodium levels, causing hyponatremia. The electrolyte imbalance, particularly hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, can provoke cardiac arrhythmias. Hyperkalemia occurs due to the release of intracellular potassium from swollen red blood cells that rupture in the hypotonic environment. These electrolyte disturbances, specifically hemodilution, hyponatremia, arrhythmias, and hyperkalemia, are characteristic findings in freshwater drowning and contribute significantly to the clinical complications observed in these cases.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Hypernatremia and hypokalemia: This combination is not typical of freshwater drowning. Hypernatremia suggests saltwater drowning due to dehydration effects from hypertonic water, which contrasts with the hemodilution seen in freshwater incidents.
  • • A. Hypernatremia and hypokalemia:
  • • C. Metabolic alkalosis and bradycardia: Metabolic alkalosis and bradycardia do not fit the presentation of freshwater drowning, where acidosis and tachyarrhythmias are more common due to the severe electrolyte imbalances, particularly hyperkalemia.
  • • C. Metabolic alkalosis and bradycardia:
  • • D. Pulmonary edema with hypercalcemia: Pulmonary edema is a potential complication of drowning; however, hypercalcemia is not related to freshwater drowning, where disturbances primarily involve sodium and potassium levels rather than calcium.
  • • D. Pulmonary edema with hypercalcemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In freshwater drowning, excessive fluid absorption causes hemodilution, leading to hyponatremia, arrhythmias due to electrolyte abnormalities, and hyperkalemia from the release of potassium from damaged red blood cells. Recognizing these changes is essential in managing the clinical complications associated with freshwater drowning.

questions.text: Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis? (INICET MAY 2023) Palpitations Elevated BNP Troponins Regional wall motion abnormalities in echo ECG suggestive of myocarditis Low LVEF in echo
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2,3,4,5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subclinical myocarditis can present with elevated cardiac biomarkers, regional wall motion abnormalities, ECG changes, and reduced LVEF, but not Palpitations, which is common in viral myocarditis.
  • ➤ Past common causes of myocarditis: Coxsackie virus types A and B.
  • ➤ Currently, Most common cause of myocarditis: Parvovirus B19 and HHV6.

questions.text: Which of the following routes of administration will not bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Oral

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The route of administration that does not bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism is Oral. This is because drugs taken orally are absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and then pass through the liver where they may be metabolically altered before reaching the systemic circulation.

  • ➤ For diabetic patients, it is recommended that less than 30% of daily calories come from fat, with saturated fat being less than 10% and trans fats being avoided. This helps in managing blood sugar levels and reducing cardiovascular risks.

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 4 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Post menopausal bleeding with a finding of endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm (5 mm or more) requires further evaluation, i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium. If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is unlikely and the likely cause of bleeding being endometrial atrophy and there is no need of a biopsy. The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis
  • • Post menopausal bleeding with a finding of endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm (5 mm or more) requires further evaluation, i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium.
  • • If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is unlikely and the likely cause of bleeding being endometrial atrophy and there is no need of a biopsy.
  • • The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In postmenopausal women with bleeding, an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasonography should prompt further evaluation with an endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy or other significant pathology.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 186, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 357

questions.text: A 60-year post-menopausal obese lady presents with backache. She has a history of Colle’s fracture 1 year back. A DEXA scan shows a T score of less than - 2.5. Which of the following is false? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Elemental calcium of 1200mg/ day is recommended

options.label: B
options.text: Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium

options.label: C
options.text: Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered

options.label: D
options.text: Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

questions.correct_answer: D. Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Management of Osteoporosis:
  • • Management of Osteoporosis:
  • • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D: Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures. Bisphosphonates: Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density. The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment. Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates. When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.
  • • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D: Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D:
  • • Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • • Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • • Bisphosphonates: Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density. The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment.
  • • Bisphosphonates:
  • • Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density. The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment.
  • • Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density.
  • • The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment.
  • • Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates. When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.
  • • Teriparatide:
  • • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates. When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.
  • • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates.
  • • When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Elemental calcium of 1200mg/day is recommended: This statement is true. Adequate calcium intake is essential for bone health, especially in postmenopausal women.
  • • Option A. Elemental calcium of 1200mg/day is recommended:
  • • Option B. Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium: This statement is true. Vitamin D3 helps in the absorption of calcium and is recommended to be given along with calcium supplements.
  • • Option B. Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium:
  • • Option C. Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered: This statement is true. Starting with teriparatide helps build bone density, and following with bisphosphonates helps maintain the gains.
  • • Option C. Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered:
  • • Option D. Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year: This statement is false. Bisphosphonates can be given for a longer duration, typically 3-5 years, depending on the patient's individual risk factors and response to therapy.
  • • Option D. Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bisphosphonates are typically recommended for a duration of 3-5 years in the treatment of osteoporosis, not limited to just 1 year.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 500, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.explanation: Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Calcification and Fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease, the mitral valve often undergoes significant morphological changes due to fibrosis and calcification, leading to stenosis with a characteristic "fish mouth" appearance. Understanding these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the progression of the disease.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady came to psychiatry OPD with symptoms of hypomania. There is a past history of maniac episode. Now, she is planning to conceive. Which of the following drug is maximum teratogenic to the fetus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Valproate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the options listed, causing significant congenital anomalies such as neural tube defects, cleft lip and palate, and cardiac anomalies, as well as poor cognitive development. It should be avoided in women who are planning to conceive or are pregnant.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe joint pain, predominantly affecting his knees. He has a history of chronic alcohol use, particularly home-distilled moonshine, and works in a battery manufacturing plant. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum uric acid levels and renal function tests showing reduced glomerular filtration rate. The joint fluid analysis is consistent with gout. Based on his occupational and environmental exposure history, what is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Saturnine gout is a type of gout caused by chronic lead intoxication, often associated with occupational exposure or ingestion of lead-contaminated substances, such as moonshine. Lead exposure results in tubulointerstitial renal damage, which impairs the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia and subsequent gout. Saturnine gout has a predilection for affecting the knee joints more frequently than the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe), which is typical in primary gout. The disproportionate elevation of uric acid relative to the reduction in glomerular filtration rate is characteristic of this condition.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Copper toxicity: Copper toxicity is mainly associated with Wilson’s disease, which causes hepatic, neurological, and psychiatric symptoms. It does not impair renal uric acid excretion and is not associated with gout.
  • • A. Copper toxicity:
  • • B. Arsenic exposure: Arsenic poisoning is associated with multisystem effects, including gastrointestinal distress, neuropathy, and skin changes, but it is not known to cause gout or hyperuricemia. Unlike lead, arsenic does not specifically impair renal uric acid excretion.
  • • B. Arsenic exposure:
  • • D. Thallium poisoning: Thallium toxicity primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms, alopecia, and neurological effects, including peripheral neuropathy, but does not typically present with gout or hyperuricemia as seen in chronic lead intoxication.
  • • D. Thallium poisoning:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Saturnine gout is a specific type of gout caused by chronic lead poisoning, which impairs renal excretion of uric acid and leads to hyperuricemia. It is often associated with occupational or environmental lead exposure, such as through battery manufacturing or consumption of lead-contaminated moonshine, and presents with gout symptoms that may predominantly affect the knees. Understanding the link between lead exposure and gout is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management in patients with relevant exposure history.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of sildenafil? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sildenafil works by inhibiting PDE-5, leading to increased levels of cGMP, which facilitates the relaxation of smooth muscle and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum. This mechanism makes option B the correct choice.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intermediate filaments

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In chronic alcoholic patients with alcoholic hepatitis, Mallory-Denk bodies are a characteristic histopathological finding. These intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions consist of aggregated cytoskeletal intermediate filaments, specifically prekeratin.

questions.text: Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination: (INICET MAY 2022) Oxygen: simple diffusion Glucose: Facilitated diffusion Sodium: voltage-gated channel Sodium: Secondary active transport Calcium: Active transport
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxygen moves by simple diffusion without a transport protein. Glucose uses facilitated diffusion with transporters. Sodium uses both voltage-gated channels and secondary active transport. Calcium uses active transport via ATP-powered pumps.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Mannitol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment for Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), which can occur during or after dialysis, involves reducing cerebral edema. The first-line treatment is mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.

questions.text: Protein of HPV that inactivates Retinoblastoma?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The protein of HPV that inactivates the retinoblastoma protein is E7, forming a complex with Rb.
  • ➤ High-risk human papilloma virus (HPV) encodes two oncoproteins, E6 and E7, which are vital to viral replication and contribute to the development of cervical cancer. HPV16 E7 can target over 20 cellular proteins, but is best known for inactivating the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor.
  • ➤ Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448132/
  • ➤ Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448132/

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer

options.label: C
options.text: Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

options.label: D
options.text: Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.correct_answer: C. Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) include:
  • • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer : COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer : COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy. Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy : COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.
  • • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer : COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
  • • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer : COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy.
  • • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer
  • • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy : COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.
  • • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy
  • • However, COCPs do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer : COCPs are known to reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • • Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
  • • Option B. Ectopic pregnancy : COCPs lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy by preventing ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus.
  • • Option B. Ectopic pregnancy
  • • Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer : COCPs decrease the risk of endometrial cancer.
  • • Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Combined oral contraceptive pills do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 124, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 489
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 124, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 489
